David was replying to me there, so I will jump in...

Mock Objects are a powerful method for breaking dependencies between
modules.  Often, these dependencies are barriers to effectively
testing.  Basically, in this case, you would write an object that
implements the RMI interface, accepts the same method calls and
returns the same results.  Then, instead of passing your code a
reference to the real RMI server, you pass it a reference to your
mock.  Then, you are in control of the interaction.  You can respond
faster, avoid setting up unnecessary resources, and can verify
everything gets called properly.

There are lots of resources at http://www.mockobjects.com to help you
get started.  There are papers, links to other packages, and
collections of downloadable mocks.

Writing mocks can be tedious, but there are several packages that
automatically generate them.  I like EasyMock
(http://www.easymock.org).  To use this, you create a MockControl
object by passing in an interface's class object, then use the
MockControl to generate the mock object instance.  The object
initially is in "record" mode, in which you define calls on the mock,
and expected return values.  Then you set "replay" mode and call your
code.  At the end, you call verify to assert that all expected calls
were received, even in the correct order if you care about that.

As for integrating junit into JDeveloper, I have never used the
product, so have nothing to contribute.
